title: 107_hr2512
content: Authorization of appropriations for United States Customs Service for enhanced activities along the Southwest border. Authorization of appropriations for United States Customs Service for enhanced activities along the Southwest border includes funding for salaries, expenses, and equipment to intensify efforts against drug smuggling and money laundering organizations, reduce traffic waiting times, and open all primary lanes during peak hours at ports on the Southwest border. The authorized amounts are $467,320,000 for fiscal year 2002, $417,832,000 for fiscal year 2003, and such sums as necessary in subsequent fiscal years. Additionally, $158,320,000 of the fiscal year 2002 funds are allocated for acquisition and deployment expenses. In fiscal year 2002, $158,320,000 is allocated for acquisition and deployment expenses related to narcotics enforcement, cargo processing, and counterterrorism technology along the Southwest border. This includes funding for various equipment such as mobile truck gamma ray systems, high energy pallet gamma ray systems, higher energy truck x-ray upgrades, nonintrusive inspection equipment operators, technology maintenance, and Industry Partnership Programs expansion. In fiscal year 2002, funding allocations include $24.3 million for higher energy truck x-ray upgrades, $41.3 million for nonintrusive inspection equipment operators, $12 million for technology maintenance, $800,000 for Industry Partnership Programs expansion, $1.6 million for canine kennel construction, $500,000 for replacement of canines, $1 million for automated targeting systems maintenance, $2.5 million for x-ray vans, $1.5 million for tool trucks, $3.5 million for refurbishing existing vans and trucks, $600,000 for contraband detection kits, $1 million for surveillance camera systems, and $1 million for surveillance systems. In fiscal year 2002, funding allocations include $24.3 million for higher energy truck x-ray upgrades, $41.3 million for nonintrusive inspection equipment operators, $12 million for technology maintenance, $800,000 for Industry Partnership Programs expansion, $1.6 million for canine kennel construction, $500,000 for replacement of canines, $1 million for automated targeting systems maintenance, $2.5 million for x-ray vans, $3.5 million for refurbishing existing vans and trucks, $600,000 for contraband detection kits, $1 million for surveillance camera systems, $1 million for surveillance systems, $14.8 million for land border vehicle targeting systems, $3 million for under vehicle inspection systems, $1.5 million for outbound passenger facilities and canopies, $1.5 million for work station replacements, $3.5 million for lane installations of Customs Automated Operations System, $5.8 million for explosive vapor trace detectors. In fiscal year 2002, funding allocations include $24.3 million for higher energy truck x-ray upgrades, $41.3 million for nonintrusive inspection equipment operators, $12 million for technology maintenance, $800,000 for Industry Partnership Programs expansion, $1.6 million for canine kennel construction, $500,000 for replacement of canines, $1 million for automated targeting systems maintenance, $2.5 million for x-ray vans, $3.5 million for refurbishing existing vans and trucks, $600,000 for contraband detection kits, $1 million for surveillance camera systems, $1 million for surveillance systems, $14.8 million for land border vehicle targeting systems, $15,832,000 for maintenance and support of equipment and training of personnel in fiscal year 2003 and each fiscal year thereafter. In fiscal year 2002, funding allocations include $15,832,000 for maintenance and support of equipment and training of personnel in fiscal year 2003 and each fiscal year thereafter. The Commissioner of Customs may use the authorized funds for technologically superior equipment if it achieves the same results as specified equipment. The Commissioner of Customs can reallocate funds for equipment that is technologically superior and achieves the same results at a lower cost than specified equipment. Up to 10 percent of the allocated amount for equipment can be reallocated. The Commissioner of Customs can reallocate funds for equipment specified in subsection (b) paragraphs (1) through (26). Up to 10 percent of the allocated amount can be reallocated for equipment specified in other paragraphs. Additionally, $79,000,000 in fiscal year 2002 and $172,000,000 in fiscal year 2003 will be used to increase staffing at the Southwest border to reduce waiting times at entry points. In fiscal years 2002 and 2003, funds will be allocated for increasing personnel at the Southwest border to reduce waiting times at entry points and combat drug smuggling and money laundering. Additionally, funds will be used for infrastructure improvements at ports of entry on the Southwest border. In fiscal years 2002 and 2003, $230,000,000 each year will be allocated for Customs Service facilities construction, improvement, and expansion at ports of entry on the Southwest Border. These funds are in addition to any other authorizations for the United States Customs Service by law.
